content.description: This route is on the North face of a small boulder behind They Call Me Mr. Tibbs. It is surprisingly fun.
Hard looking roof with a bad landing that probably isn't as bad as it looks and feels.
content.protection: Pads, but spotters are more important.

content.description: This is a relatively long lip traverse with a cruxy finish. The route starts as low as is comfortable on the lower right side of the boulder.
content.protection: Pads. The landing is slanted, but the entire climb is low to the ground.
content.location: This boulder sits in between Easter Island and They Call Me Mr. Tibbs.

content.description: Starts on a large jug as far right as you can go without falling off of the platform that forms the lading. Climbs up and left to a scary top out. It climbs like a crack climb with foot and hand jams making it much easier and more secure. Top out before traversing all the way left (safer and easier).
content.protection: Pads and a spotter. The landing get worse as you get higher.
content.location: Once you are in the are this is hard to miss.

content.description:
Starts on a big undercling with good feet. Climbs left using the obvious diagonal rail and up through harder terrain.  

  Beautiful wall with great rock.
content.location: It's a West facing wall that is south of the main Tibbs area, and slightly down the hill. It's easy to find from the south end of the red trail. Short, relatively easy approach for the area.

content.description: This is a strange but very fun route. It starts in a corner in the lower right corner of the boulder. The grade is extremely speculative.
content.location: This boulder is slightly north of the Tibbs area. It stands alone at the same elevation and faces north west.

content.description: Start on the right side of the small boulder behind They Call Me Mr. Tibbs. Right hand starts on the arete and left hand underclinging on the large horizontal. This is a fun one move wonder.
content.location: Behind They Call Me Mr. Tibbs.

content.description: Starts on the jug and climbs left and up. Very fun and gymnastic route.
content.location: 100 or so feet north of It's Spectacular facing North.

content.description: Starts on a large sidepull on the same boulder as Tibbs ate Rufus. Climbs straight up the blank face using the right arete.

Very fun and easy route with a good landing. It is a stand stand start on an obvious ledge for feet, a good triangular right hand hold and the left arete. Climb using compression and toe and heel hooks.
content.location: This is the most obvious boulder in the area. It is on the edge of the Tibbs area and it faces southwest.

content.description: Shaded in the morning and sunny in the afternoon. This area is high up on the ridge line which makes it feel secluded. It is a wonderful place to climb.
